ofx:section.ofx:title: GeoServer
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph: GeoServer is an open-source server written in Java and allows users to share, process and edit geospatial data.

Designed for interoperability, it publishes data from any major spatial data source using open standards. GeoServer has evolved to become an easy method for connecting existing information to Virtual Globes such as Google Earth and NAS World Wind as well as to web-based maps such as OpenLayers, Google Maps and Bing Maps.

GeoServer functions as the reference implementation of the Open Geospatial Consortium Web Feature Service (WFS) standard, and also implements the Web Map Service (WMS), Web Coverage Service (WCS) and Web Processing Service (WPS) specifications.

ofx:section.ofx:title: Installation
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph: Before installing GeoServer a user named geoserver has to be created by the user root.

After finishing your installation, you should do a test run with the current geoserver installation. First, change from the user "root" to "geoserver", it is necessary to deploy the server with this user, otherwise the rights are changed back to root. Now go to the geoserverx.x.x/bin folder of the current geoserver installation and run the ./start.sh. The current geoserver installation should now start.

There are several individual configurations required for GeoServer to properly show the maps required for this information system. These configurations include:

l:item.ofx:paragraph: A new workspace has to be created where all settings are set.
The data stores have to be configured. The most important one is the connection to the PostGIS database.
The coverage store need to be added for each raster data source.
The feature types are individual tables of the data store and provide access to vector data.
All layers have to be configured, either with a coverage stroe or a feature type.
For each layer a individual style has to be configured with a Styled Layer Descriptor (SLD).
